Row.Text: Sauron, the Lord of the Rings, was a fallen Maia, the creator of the One Ring, and the most trusted lieutenant of his master Morgoth (Melkor, the first Dark Lord). After Morgoth's defeat in the First Age, Sauron became the second Dark Lord and strove to conquer Arda, creating the rings of power for this purpose.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] In the Second Age, Sauron became known as the Dark Lord of Mordor and his fortress of Barad-dûr was completed. he conquered nearly all of Middle-earth during the War of the Elves and Sauron. However, the armies of Númenór's King Tar-Minastir were finally able to defeat him at the last battle. Defeated but not vanquished, Sauron retreated back to Mordor and began recouping his strength over the many centuries. Towards the end of the Second Age, Sauron was once again powerful enough to raise again large armies to attempt to rule Middle-earth. Sauron's rise in power and apparent intention to crown himself the King of all Men offended the Númenóreans. He was defeated in the War of the Last Alliance of Elves and Men. During the battle, Isildur managed to cut off Sauron's finger with the ring on it, causing the destruction of his corporeal form and scattering his armies. After spending hundreds of years lying dormant and slowly regaining his strength, Sauron returned to power in the Third Age, but was finally defeated in the War of the Ring through the destruction of the One Ring.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The time has come for you to rise again Dark Lord Sauron. Will your armies bring about the destruction of your enemies? Or will you let them slip by you and destroy you from within? Can you build a civilization that will stand the test of time?

Mordor, the "black land", was Sauron's base of power in his quest for dominion over all of Middle-Earth. Mordor was defended on three sides by two unassialable mountain ranges providing a natural fortress against his enemies. The northwest corner of Mordor the deep valley of Udun was the only entrance for large armies. To the southwest lay the arid plateau of the Gorgoroth and Mount Doom. The southern part of mordor called Nurn was sligtly more fertile and moist enough for slave farming.

In Tolkien's writings, orcs were cruel, wicked, and bad-hearted, and hated everybody and everything, particularly the orderly and prosperous, short in stature and humanoid in general shape. They were squat, broad, flat-nosed, sallow-skinned, bow-legged, with wide mouths and slant eyes, long arms, dark skin, and fangs.
The Morannon Orc is a powerful standard melee unit during the Classical Era. Upon defeating an enemy the Morannon orc eats its victims to regenerate health.
Self-healing melee unit. Replaces the Swordsman.
Great Generals are earned 25% Faster. Pay 25% less for land unit maintenance.
There is no life in the void. . . Only death.
You cannot hide. I see you!

The Nazgûl, Ring-wraiths, also referred to as the Black Riders or as the Nine, were the dreaded ring-bound servants of the Dark Lord Sauron in Middle-earth throughout the Second and Third ages, and they dwelt during the Third Age in Minas Morgul. Once nine great Kings of Men, they were all given Rings of Power. The Nine took them without question and subsequently, after the forging of the One Ring, became slaves of Sauron and later his chief lieutenants. After centuries the effect of the rings left the kings spectral, invisible to all but Sauron and whoever wore the One Ring. Their rings were forged approximately SA 1500.
The Nazgul increase the combat strength your nearby units by 15% while decreasing the combat strength of nearby enemies by 15%. Can detect invisible units.
Great Generals that the Enemies Fear. Can detect invisible units.
